item.title: The Evil-nerd-commenter Package for Emacs
item.description:
youtube

Use the package evil-nerd-commenter to comment and uncomment lines in Emacs more easily. One doesn't need to use evil-mode for this to work. Install evil-nerd-commenter, then add this code to your init.el file. ;; evil-nerd-commenter (you don't need to use evil-mode to use this) (evilnc-default-hotkeys) () (defun matlab-mode-hook-config () (local-set-key (kbd "M-;") 'evilnc-comment-or-uncomment-lines)) https://github.com/emacselements https://emacselements.com/

item.title: Emacs Notmuch with Multiple Addresses & Auto Encryption
item.description:
youtube

This guide provides a quick setup for configuring Notmuch with GNU Emacs to handle multiple email addresses and enable automatic encryption. Notmuch has been incredibly useful for me over the past year, and I hope this guide helps new users overcome initial challenges. Video notes: https://thanosapollo.org/posts/emacs-notmuch-video-guide/

item.title: EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: Common Lisp images communicating like-a-human through shared Emacs slime and eev
item.description:
youtube

screwlisp (he/him, they/them) This is the Q&A for the talk at https://youtu.be/hy5i6Qb6fYE . 00:00 Opening 02:08 Q: What do you mean by "the agent is running slowly"? 03:00 Q: Do you think that it would be too hard to add a second way to send commands from Common Lisp to Emacs? 06:37 Q: What is the leonardo system? 09:27 Q: What is LambdaMOO, and how do we use it? 11:01 Q: It seems like you're trying to build a more restrictive Turing test using the input / output logs of an emacs conversation. Is that accurate? 15:52 Q: What do you mean by slowly? You can view this and other resources using free/libre software at https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/commonlisp . This video is available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) license.

item.title: EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: Emacs as a fully-fledged reference manager - Vidianos Giannitsis (he/him)
item.description:
youtube

This is the Q&A for the talk at https://youtu.be/XjhnY4WuQRQ . 00:00 Q: Have you try ivy-bibtex/bibtex-completion.el, how it compares to ebib? 01:32 Q: Do you find showing abstract on your navigation panel helpful? 03:53 Q: it seems that there's a meta problem here: too much information. Do your tools reduce cognative load? 06:44 Q: When you download a new article, how do you integrate its file to your database? For example, do you move and rename the file manually? 10:02 Q: What about annotations with ereaders: viewing and taking on emacs or ereader touchscreen highlighting and notes, org-noter I think would be an alternative out of ebook annotation alternative? 12:52 Q: How well do you feel about making notes on web sites, pdf, videos? I know pdf is usually good but others I am less sure about. 16:19 Q: How do you add a new article from scratch, a pdf that you did not have in your bib file? How do you generate the 'bib' entry with metadata and abstract? 18:15 Q: When do you fact check every detail for a bib entry? The author names, published journal, doi stuff. You can view this and other resources using free/libre software at https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/reference . This video is available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) license.

item.title: EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: An introduction to the Emacs Reader - Divyá
item.description:
youtube

EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: An introduction to the Emacs Reader Divyá This is the Q&A for the talk at https://youtu.be/KQBXTSg_Occ . 00:00 Q: Is there scope for integrating the C library into Emacs itself with muPDF becoming an optional dependency? 00:59 Q: The dynamic modules sound great, and it's amazing they're there since 2017. Why is it so slow to take off, do you think? Is there prior art with them? 03:02 Q: How is pdf-tools difficult to install? I install it using the built in package manager. 04:41 Q: What tool(s) did you use to measure the memory usage between the three packages? 05:49 Q: How is the conversion between ELisp and the foreign language type system done? For example when interfacing with a C++ library that makes heavy use of C++ object system and templates? 08:17 Q: Can one look at pdf metadata with emacs-reader? Can annotations be added? Does it understand forms? Can it handle encrypted pdfs? 09:28 Q: How can I associate ODT files to open with emacs-reader? 10:26 Q: If a pdf file is open in emacs-reader and I regenerate the pdf with some changes, does emacs-reader actually refresh the pdf on its own or do I have to reload the pdf? 11:49 Q: What are the challenges with integrating with SyncTeX and AucTeX? This would be great to see as pdf-tools handles this well. 12:35 Q: Will you be giving another talk on the architecture you went over? A deep-dive there would be awesome. 12:59 Q: Is there search functionality? Something like isearch and occur? 13:30 Q: Does dynamic module prevent customization that Elisp usually provide? (Advices, Hooks, etc). 15:31 Q: Do you usually create an Elisp shim from the FFI and then use them with Elisp code? 16:44 Q: Is searching on the roadmap? Or is it already available as a feature? 17:48 Q: Will there be occur-like searching? 18:28 Q: What is your timing expectation for it to appear on ELPA? You can view this and other resources using free/libre software at https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/reader . This video is available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) license.

item.title: EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: Interactive Python programming in Emacs - David Vujic (he/him)
item.description:
youtube

EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: Interactive Python programming in Emacs David Vujic (he/him) This is the Q&A for the talk at https://youtu.be/uACM4a5MPQM . 00:00 Developing Python in Emacs 01:16 Q: How long have you been using Emacs? 02:39 Q: What editor were you primarily using before? 04:00 Q: Do you have your Emacs connect to the IPython kernel over the XMPP socket that IPython sets up? 05:38 Q: Not sure if you've explored Org Babel, but what are the benefits of using your approach over Org? 07:05 Q: Have you seen marimo.io notebooks? It uses standard Python. 08:20 Q: what LLM did you say you've used? 10:28 Q: Are you building your own Emacs, or using the system packages? 12:40 Q: Are you involved with local Emacs meetups? 14:24 Q: Can you repeat the name of the LLM that you specifically mentioned there? - ECA 18:08 Wrapping up You can view this and other resources using free/libre software at https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/python . This video is available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) license.

item.title: EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: Emacs, editors, and LLM driven workflows - Andrew Hyatt (he/him)
item.description:
youtube

This is the Q&A for the talk at https://youtu.be/U3kbEabBJ_s . 00:00 Q: My biggest question with AI code editors trying to integrate with Emacs is -- are the AI code editors able to read unsaved buffers and not just saved files? 02:20 Q: Personally I don't agree with the comment you made about VS Code usage dying out because I see companies/products pushing for tightly-integrated VS-Code agents/products like Windsurf. Thoughts? 03:47 Q: Do you have any thoughts about the environmental cost of using LLMs - either the training of models we can download and use locally, or the larger, commercial models used from the cloud? 06:09 Q: I must say, I liked your conclusion, but I differ insofar as you said that VS Code differ from Emacs because the former is not as easy to adapt as the latter. Why should Microsoft not adapt VS Code as we adapt Emacs for the new era of coding? And why would VS Code be harder hit? Could you please elaborate on this point? 09:14 Q: Do you think that we are falling behind in productivity as Emacs users? Compared to all these VSCode forks that have 1000 buttons and textboxes everywhere (i.e. much richer UIs which are basically webpages). 12:17 Q: I've been using Claude Code extensively. I recently switched to Agent Shell with Claude Code. Have you tried it, what are your thoughts? 14:32 Q: In terms of agent selection, what has your experience been with different agents, and have you had any success with hosting your own models and using open weights? 17:33 Q: I'm reading angst in your thinking about AI/editing. What are you excited about? 19:47 Q: Why does it matter to have a richer UI? All that is left is basically writing and getting the results. 22:25 Wrapping up 23:23 Q: I have 45+ years editing, programming. I'm not sure I can think about things without thinking of buffers, editors etc. Is this a handicap/should we just have people with no experience with code learn to prompt? You can view this and other resources using free/libre software at https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/llm . This video is available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) license.

item.title: EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: Reading and writing emails in GNU Emacs with Gnus - Amin Bandali (he/him)
item.description:
youtube

This is the Q&A for the talk at https://youtu.be/0Pu8oqdsSig . 00:00 Q: I noticed that it took a considerable amount of time to send email. Is it possible to configure gnus to use an external smtp client to send emails? 01:17 Q: Is the dovecot workaround actually a solution? 03:07 Q: Do you have experience with mu4e or Notmuch, and why would you say Gnus is worth using compared to these? 06:05 Q: At my organization, we're forced to use OAuth with outlook and they've also blacklisted all email clients except thunderbird (but they don't support it, only the webmail or the outlook app). Do you know if this is something that can be circumvented in Gnus? 13:18 Comment: Liked how I started with a clean setup 17:34 Comment: They would have liked to see a quick demo of Gnus while it is fully configured and tweaked 18:22 My init file 19:34 Mail splitting 19:52 Gnus parameters 21:31 Custom signatures 22:05 Other customizations You can view this and other resources using free/libre software at https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/gnus . This video is available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) license.

item.title: EmacsConf 2025 Q&A: org-gmail: A deep integration of Gmail into your Org Mode
item.description:
youtube

Bala Ramadurai (he/him) This is the Q&A for the talk at https://youtu.be/8P93UBYrUB8 . 00:00 Feedback: Consider using similar background (dark-only / light-only) throughout to help with eye strain. 00:29 Q: Should I know all my contact's email addresses by heart? Or is some kind of contact list? 01:33 Q: What would it take to use the org pieces of this with, e.g., offlineimap or other non-Gmail mail setups? 02:50 Q: Do you worry about sending some info to a wrong person? Due to some unseen technical issues, for example, due to memory overflow. 04:11 Comment: You should say what org-gmail is and is not, goals and non goals "which in this case is more helpful" to help people get their head around this. 05:43 Q: How does it handle attachments? If it doesn't, do you have a plan to add this feature? You can view this and other resources using free/libre software at https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/gmail . This video is available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) license.

item.title: I wrote a thing for Emacs, but don't call it a "plugin"
item.description:
youtube

Let me show you a typical process of writing a relatively simple Emacs package and publishing it on MELPA. I'll show you https://github.com/agzam/wiktionary-bro.el We'll dive into some technical nuances, talk about some history of Lisp, explore some Emacs features. 0:00:00 Introduction & Preamble 0:00:25 Why Emacs Has Packages, Not Plugins 0:02:21 The Power of Etymology 0:04:44 Why Wiktionary is Essential 0:05:51 Video Structure Overview 0:06:00 Package Demo 0:06:32 wiktionary-bro Homepage 0:07:03 Live Demo in Emacs 0:07:24 DWIM Command Explained 0:08:01 External Links & Browser Integration 0:08:37 Language Selection 0:09:05 Org-Mode Features 0:09:40 Conjugation Tables 0:11:10 Technical Deep Dive 0:12:05 Package Repositories (MELPA, ELPA) 0:14:29 Package Header Requirements 0:14:48 Lambda Calculus History (1930s) 0:17:25 John McCarthy & Birth of Lisp 0:18:06 s-expressions Origin Story 0:19:09 Why Lisp Matters Today 0:21:02 Structural Editing 0:22:24 REPL-Driven Development 0:24:40 Package Headers Deep Dive 0:25:05 Package Dependencies 0:27:28 Doom Emacs File Templates 0:28:11 Required Libraries 0:28:28 Destructuring in Lisp 0:31:09 Features List (1000+ Packages!) 0:33:32 defgroup & Customization UI 0:36:43 Faces 0:37:24 describe-face Command 0:38:00 Changing Face Colors Live 0:39:40 Frames vs Windows 0:41:24 Interactive vs Non-Interactive Functions 0:43:32 Global vs Buffer-Local Variables 0:44:20 buffer-local Variables Demo 0:46:10 Keymaps (Sparse vs Full) 0:48:52 define-derived-mode 0:49:40 Hooks System 0:50:20 org-open-at-point Hook 0:53:00 add-hook with Local Parameter 0:55:40 Predicate Function Convention 0:56:40 Private Function Convention 0:57:00 save-excursion 1:00:30 cl-letf Function Overriding 1:02:03 Overriding shr Functions 1:03:20 Extended Regex Syntax 1:03:40 regex-quote Helper 1:04:18 regex-builder Interactive Tool 1:06:40 MELPA Repository Structure 1:07:09 Recipe Format 1:08:26 package-lint 1:08:46 checkdoc for Documentation 1:09:58 MELPA Review Process 1:11:13 Conclusion & Final Thoughts Opening music: https://soundcloud.com/incredfx/at-dooms-gate

item.title: Xah Talk Show Ep719 new CSS units, lh cap ic. emacs xah css mode. typing chinese in emacs.
item.description:
youtube

This video from the Xah Talk Show focuses on new CSS length units and their practical application. The host, Xah Lee, updates his CSS tutorial with these new units and demonstrates their usage and the challenges encountered during testing. Key topics covered include: Introduction to new CSS Length Units (0:40-1:50): lh (line height), cap (capital letters height), ic (Chinese character "water" width/height), and rcap, ric, and rlh. Demonstrating LH unit (3:31-10:24): Test the LH unit for font-size. He initially faces issues but later discovers a typo in "font-size" (8:17-8:20). Updating Emacs CSS Mode (10:30-15:20): update his Emacs CSS mode to recognize and highlight the newly introduced CSS units. Understanding IC unit and Chinese Input in Emacs (17:53-21:00): The video delves into the IC unit, which is based on the width/height of the Chinese character for "water." Xah Lee demonstrates how to type Chinese characters using emacs's own input method. Understanding cap unit (22:25-26:00): Xah Lee explains the cap unit, which represents the nominal height of capital letters. He clarifies the long-standing problem in CSS where font-size doesn't always accurately reflect the actual visual size of letters due to font design variations. Demonstrating Font Family Impact on Layout (1:00:29-1:02:50): The host demonstrates how changing font families can significantly alter the layout of a webpage, even when the font-size remains constant. Discovery of a Firefox Bug (37:50-40:50, 1:10:02-1:10:55): Xah Lee uncovers a potential bug in Firefox where specifying a font family like "Arial" without a generic fallback (e.g., sans-serif) results in Firefox defaulting to a serif font. This behavior is inconsistent with other browsers like Brave and is identified as a significant issue for web development. Discussion on Ergonomic Keyboards (1:05:15-1:08:41): Towards the end of the video, Xah Lee briefly discusses ergonomic keyboards, comparing the Ultimate Hacking Keyboard (UHK80) and the Glove 80. He emphasizes the importance of key switch lightness and notes the different layouts (slanted vs. ortholinear) of the two keyboards. code at http://xahlee.info/talk_show/xah_talk_show_ep719.html If browser says security error, that is because it auto changes URL from HTTP to HTTPS. It's a way to censor 22 million old websites. Remove the S in HTTPS. Or use brave browser or safari.

item.title: EmacsConf 2025: Emacs, editors, and LLM driven workflows - Andrew Hyatt (he/him)
item.description:
youtube

https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/llm You can view this and other resources using free/libre software at https://emacsconf.org/2025/talks/llm . This video is available under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-SA 4.0) license.
